newsitem.title: UK: Funds lured less to high-yield debt in Q3 - survey.
newsitem.headline: Funds lured less to high-yield debt in Q3 - survey.

text.p: Global investors raised allocations to U.S., German and British bonds in the last quarter, but surprisingly cut weightings in high-yielding markets of Spain, Sweden and Italy, data from Paribas Capital Markets showed.

In a survey of 146 multi-currency investors, Paribas found a "marked contrast" in portfolio positions in high-yielding markets in the third quarter 1996, "with some investors outright bullish and others outright bearish", it said in a statement.
Paribas said there had been a pronounced shift towards U.S. dollar bonds, reflecting "a belief that the worst is over and that the spread to Europe has become very attractive."
Denmark and Britain, who both have opt-out clauses on European Economic and Monetary Union, proved popular places for bond investors, the data showed.

"The Danish bond market remains a favourite holding by investors and the cheapness of the British market within Europe has seen investors reweighting positions there during the past three months," the statement said.
Paribas said that of the 146 investors surveyed, 31 had funds of less than $1.0 billion, 62 had funds of between $1.0 and $5.0 billion, and 53 had funds of $5.0 billion or over.
The survey, undertaken from September 23 to September 27, canvassed investors for information on bond portfolios -- including both government and corporate debt.
The results are presented in the form of an index, with 100 being maximum overweight, 0 being maximum underweight, and 50 being neutral.
